(Use relations: 1 Byte = 8 bits, 1 MB = 1000 B, 1 GB = 1000 M and so on)

questions.question_text_1: Consider a server that has an Intel i5 processor, 64 GB RAM, 1 TB Hard disk with 3 Gbps network connection. If a client accesses a web page, it requires 1.5 MB. Calculate the maximum number of such requests per second the server can handle. (Use relations: 1 Byte = 8 bits, 1 MB = 1000 B, 1 GB = 1000 M and so on).

questions.question_text_1: The speed vs. throughput characteristics of a typical HDD is shown in the figure below. If this HDD is to be used as a replacement of an SSD whose read/write speed is 450 MB/s. At what speed (in RPM) should the disk of HDD rotate with to deliver the same performance as that of the SSD?

props.summary:
Here’s a structured summary of the **core topics, concepts, principles, and equations** essential for the **"Diploma Level: Modern Application Development 1"** exam, along with **Mermaid knowledge graphs** to visualize relationships. --- --- ### **1. Core Topics & Concepts** #### **A. Web Development Fundamentals** 1. **URL Structure** - Components: `Protocol` (e.g., `https`), `Domain Name` (e.g., `www.example.com`), `Path/Directory` (e.g., `/home`), `Query Parameters` (e.g., `?user=Mad1&key=madcs2003`). - **Equation/Example**: ```plaintext https://www.example.com/home?user=Mad1&key=madcs2003 Protocol: https Domain: www.example.com Path: /home Query: user=Mad1&key=madcs2003 ``` 2. **HTTP Methods** - `GET`: Retrieve data. - `POST`: Submit data (e.g., form submissions). - `PUT`: Update existing data. - `DELETE`: Remove data. - **Flask Example**: ```python @app.route('/myshop', methods=['POST']) def create_shop(): new_data = request.get_json() # Process data ``` 3. **Flask Framework** - **Routing**: Define endpoints (e.g., `@app.route('/')`). - **Templates**: Use `render_template` to render HTML with dynamic data (Jinja2 syntax). - **Jinja2 Filters**: `{{ item | length }}`, `{% if condition %}`. - **Loops**: `{% for item in list %}`. - **Request Handling**: Access query parameters (`request.args`) or JSON data (`request.get_json()`). - **Redirects & Errors**: `redirect(url_for('route'))`, `abort(404)`. - **Flask-RESTful**: Build APIs with `Resource`, `Api`, and `reqparse`. - Example: ```python class Add(Resource): def post(self): parser = reqparse.RequestParser() parser.add_argument('Name', required=True) args = parser.parse_args() return {"Name": args['Name']} ``` 4. **Flask-SQLAlchemy** - **Model Definition**: ```python class Person(db.Model): id = db.Column(db.Integer, primary_key=True) name = db.Column(db.String(50)) ``` - **Queries**: - `Person.query.filter_by(name="Alice").first()` - `Person.query.get(1)` - **Update**: ```python workers = Worker.query.filter_by(Gender='Female').all() for worker in workers: worker.Salary += 500 db.session.commit() ``` - **Relationships**: - One-to-Many: `db.relationship("ChildModel", backref="parent")`. - Foreign Keys: `db.ForeignKey("parent.id")`. 5. **Jinja2 Templating** - **Macros**: Reusable HTML snippets. ```html {% macro display(list) %} {% for item in list %}

{{ item }}

{% endfor %} {% endmacro %} ``` - **Conditionals**: ```html {% if user.is_authenticated %}

Welcome, {{ user.name }}!

{% else %}

Access denied.

{% endif %} ``` 6. **HTML/CSS** - **CSS Selectors**: - `element.class` (e.g., `p.class1`). - `#id` (e.g., `#header-id1`). - **Inline vs. Internal vs. External CSS**: - Inline: `

`. - Internal: ``. - External: ``. - **Box Model**: `margin`, `border`, `padding`, `content`. - **Flexbox/Grid**: Layout techniques (not covered in questions but fundamental). 7. **Testing with Pytest** - **Fixtures**: Reusable test data. ```python @pytest.fixture def items(): return ["Books", "Pens"] ``` - **Assertions**: ```python def test_example(items): assert "Books" in items ``` - **Test Isolation**: Each test runs independently; modifications in one test don’t affect others. 8. **Performance Calculations** - **Bandwidth**: Convert units (Bytes ↔ bits, KB ↔ MB ↔ GB). - **Equation**: ``` Bandwidth (Gbps) = (Request Size (KB) * Number of Requests * 8 bits/Byte) / (1000^3 bits/Gb) ``` - Example: For 12,500 requests of 180 KB each: ``` Total data = 12,500 * 180 KB = 2,250,000 KB = 2.25 GB = 2.25 * 8 Gb = 18 Gb Bandwidth = 18 Gb / 1 second = 18 Gbps Increase = 18 - Original Bandwidth (calculated similarly). ``` - **Time Complexity**: For sorting (O(n log n)), calculate scaled time: - **Equation**: ``` T2 = T1 * (n2 * log(n2)) / (n1 * log(n1)) ``` - Example: For `n1=500`, `T1=100s`, `n2=1200`: ``` T2 = 100 * (1200 * log(1200)) / (500 * log(500)) ≈ 273s ``` 9. **Database Operations** - **SQLite Queries**: - `CREATE INDEX`: Improve search performance. ```sql CREATE UNIQUE INDEX idx_name ON table_name (column1, column2) WHERE condition; ``` - `LIKE`: Pattern matching (`%` wildcard). ```python Worker.query.filter(Worker.Name.like('F%')).all() # Names starting with 'F' ``` - **Relationships in SQLAlchemy**: - **One-to-Many**: ```python class State(db.Model): cities = db.relationship("City", backref="state") class City(db.Model): state_id = db.Column(db.Integer, db.ForeignKey("state.id")) ``` - **Accessing Related Objects**: - `state_object.cities` → List of cities. - `city_object.state` → Parent state. 10. **API Development** - **Flask-RESTful**: - Define resources with `GET`, `POST`, `PUT`, `DELETE`. - Use `marshal_with` to format responses. ```python out_fields = {"name": fields.String, "age": fields.Integer} @marshal_with(out_fields) def get(self): return {"name": "Alice", "age": 30} ``` - **Request Parsing**: ```python parser = reqparse.RequestParser() parser.add_argument("name", required=True) args = parser.parse_args() ``` 11. **Error Handling** - **HTTP Status Codes**: - `200 OK`: Success. - `400 Bad Request`: Client error. - `401 Unauthorized`: Authentication failed. - `404 Not Found`: Resource missing. - `500 Internal Server Error`: Server issue. - **Flask Error Handlers**: ```python @app.errorhandler(404) def not_found(error): return "Page not found", 404 ``` 12. **Hardware Performance** - **HDD vs. SSD**: - Throughput (MB/s) vs. RPM (rotations per minute). - **Equation**: Higher RPM → Higher throughput (non-linear). - **Server Capacity**: - **Requests per Second**: ``` Max Requests = Bandwidth (Gbps) / Request Size (GB) ``` - Example: 3 Gbps bandwidth, 1.5 MB (0.0015 GB) per request: ``` Max Requests = 3 / 0.0015 = 2000 requests/sec ``` --- --- ### **2. Key Equations (Mathematics/Performance)** | **Concept** | **Equation** | **Example** | |---------------------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------------| | Bandwidth Calculation | `Bandwidth (Gbps) = (Data Size (GB) * 8) / Time (s)` | 10,000 requests * 150 KB = 1.5 GB → 1.5 * 8 = 12 Gb → 12 Gbps bandwidth. | | Time Complexity (Sorting) | `T2 = T1 * (n2 * log(n2)) / (n1 * log(n1))` | `T2 = 100 * (1200 * log(1200)) / (500 * log(500)) ≈ 273s`. | | Requests per Second | `Max Requests = Bandwidth (Gbps) / (Request Size (GB) * 8)` | 3 Gbps / (1.5 MB * 8) = 250 requests/sec. | | HDD RPM to Throughput | Empirical (graph-based); higher RPM → higher throughput (non-linear). | 450 MB/s SSD ≈ 28,800 RPM HDD (extrapolated from graph). | --- --- ### **3. Mermaid Knowledge Graphs** #### **Graph 1: Web Development Core Concepts** ```mermaid graph TD A[Web Development] --> B[Frontend] A --> C[Backend] B --> D[HTML/CSS] B --> E[JavaScript] D --> F[CSS Selectors] D --> G[Box Model] C --> H[Flask] C --> I[Database] H --> J[Routing] H --> K[Templating Jinja2] H --> L[Request Handling] I --> M[SQLAlchemy] I --> N[SQLite Queries] M --> O[Relationships] M --> P[CRUD Operations] ``` #### **Graph 2: Flask Framework** ```mermaid graph TD A[Flask] --> B[Routing] A --> C[Templating] A --> D[Request Handling] A --> E[Error Handling] A --> F[Flask-RESTful] B --> G[@app.route] C --> H[Jinja2 Syntax] C --> I[Macros] D --> J[request.args] D --> K[request.get_json] E --> L[abort] E --> M[errorhandler] F --> N[Resource] F --> O[Api] F --> P[reqparse] ``` #### **Graph 3: Database Operations** ```mermaid graph TD A[Database] --> B[SQLAlchemy] A --> C[SQLite] B --> D[Model Definition] B --> E[Relationships] B --> F[Queries] E --> G[One-to-Many] E --> H[Foreign Keys] F --> I[filter_by] F --> J[update] F --> K[commit] C --> L[CREATE INDEX] C --> M[LIKE Clause] ``` #### **Graph 4: Performance & Hardware** ```mermaid graph TD A[Performance] --> B[Bandwidth] A --> C[Time Complexity] A --> D[Hardware] B --> E[Gbps Calculation] C --> F[O(n log n)] D --> G[HDD vs SSD] D --> H[RPM to Throughput] E --> I[Request Size] F --> J[Scaled Time] G --> K[Graph Interpretation] ``` #### **Graph 5: Testing with Pytest** ```mermaid graph TD A[Testing] --> B[Pytest] B --> C[Fixtures] B --> D[Assertions] B --> E[Test Isolation] C --> F[@pytest.fixture] D --> G[assert statement] E --> H[Independent Tests] ``` --- --- ### **4. Exam Tips** 1. **Flask Routing**: Memorize how to define routes and handle different HTTP methods. 2. **Jinja2**: Practice loops, conditionals, and macros. 3. **SQLAlchemy**: Focus on model definitions, relationships, and CRUD operations. 4. **Performance Calculations**: Understand unit conversions (Bytes ↔ bits, KB ↔ MB ↔ GB) and time complexity scaling. 5. **Error Handling**: Know HTTP status codes and Flask’s `abort`/`errorhandler`. 6. **CSS**: Be comfortable with selectors (class, ID) and the box model. 7. **Testing**: Understand fixtures and assertions in Pytest.
